ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Speaking, grammar, reading, and more insight to Chinese culture.
Language to talk about Chinese politics. Knowledge on chinese culture

This was my first Chinese class at Yale. I improved noticeably at comprehending real-time speech, largely due simply to the demands of having to follow along with Zhan Laoshi speaking in the class. I also became more confident at speaking without lots of preparation in advance. This course introduced more specifics about the differences between formal/written and spoken Chinese as well, which helped my essay writing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The workload was very high but all the assignments were helpful. Chan Laoshi is also a strength of the course because of her engaging teaching style and her sense of humor.
great Chinese class but very tedious homework assignments. Felt like a lot of busy work.

The course had very few weaknesses (Yale's Chinese department continues to live up to its reputation for excellence!). Strengths were Zhan Laoshi's upbeat, humorous, and interactive teaching, as well as her clear explanations of the minute differences between various words and usages. Every error a student made seemed to be yet another opportunity for explaining something to the class in more depth or introducing a new and better word. While I of course picked up a lot of new vocabulary and grammar over the semester, the speed of the class meant that I doubt I'll remember a good portion of it -- but that's not really a weakness in my book, because the speed/density was what made the class so effective. The only other issue that I can think of is that the responsibilities for class time were not always consistent: some days, we had a full hour of group discussions that required plenty of speaking for all the students, but other days, when new material was being introduced, you could get by only speaking once during the entire class. I was always anxious about being able to speak well enough, so I never felt comfortable enough to disengage on those days, but I can imagine that some more confident/advanced students might have that temptation.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you're willing to put a lot of time in, then it is worth it because your Chinese level will get much better.
Yes! If you want to expand your vocabulary and knowledge on life in China.
Yes - its a great course to consolidate what you have learned previously, whether that was in high school, CHNS 130/140 or during the summer Light Fellowship.

I would absolutely recommend this course. It's challenging, sure, but that allows you to really progress in a way that's actually noticeable. And you'd be hard-pressed to find a more supportive and well-put-together language-learning environment anywhere else. You'll never feel lost.
